title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the aluminium block felt colder than the plastic block in the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was at a lower temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was at a higher temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it conducted heat away from the hand faster than the plastic block.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it conducted heat towards the hand faster than the plastic block.

options.label: A
options.text: Because the aluminium block was at a higher temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the aluminium block was at a lower temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the aluminium block conducted heat to the ice cube more quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the aluminium block conducted heat away from the ice cube more quickly.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because the hard drive conducted heat towards the hand faster than the book.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Because the hard drive was at a higher temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the hard drive was at a lower temperature.

title: Why do we pass gas? - Purna Kashyap

multiple-choice.question: What is the normal daily phenomenon of passing gas due to?

options.label: B
options.text: Bacteria in our intestines digesting parts of food

options.label: C
options.text: Eating foods with high amounts of indigestible carbohydrates

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of enzymes in the body

multiple-choice.question: What do gut bacteria get their nutrition primarily from?

options.label: B
options.text: Undigested food, such as carbohydrates and proteins

multiple-choice.question: What are the most common gaseous products of bacterial fermentation?
What is the foul smell of gas usually due to?
Which foods can cause increased passage of gas?

options.label: A
options.text: Beans, lentils, dairy products, onions, garlic, leeks, radishes, potatoes, oats, wheat, cauliflower, broccoli, cabbage, and Brussels sprouts

multiple-choice.question: What happens if you starve the bacteria that digest complex carbohydrates?

options.label: B
options.text: They will start eating the sugars in the mucus lining of your intestines

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of abnormal increased flatulence?
What is the role of methanogens in the gut?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce methane and reduce the total volume of gas

options.label: B
options.text: They produce carbon dioxide and hydrogen

multiple-choice.question: What is the interaction between intestinal bacteria that allows them to flourish?

options.label: A
options.text: Directly consuming undigested food or using what other bacteria produce

options.label: B
options.text: Producing methane and reducing the total volume of gas

multiple-choice.question: What is the amount and type of gas produced in the gut due to?

options.label: B
options.text: The bacteria present in the gut

options.label: C
options.text: The enzymes present in the gut

title: What if the Earth stopped spinning?

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the Earth suddenly stopped spinning?

options.label: A
options.text: The oceans would surge onto land in tsunamis kilometers high and wash over nearly all dry land.

options.label: B
options.text: The Sun would seem to freeze in the sky as days became not 24 hours long but 365 days long.

options.label: C
options.text: The friction alone, caused by the now stopped Earth colliding with winds, would be enough to cause massive fires, unparalleled erosion and damage to anything strong enough to stay put after the initial braking.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth's protective magnetic field would cease to exist and we would be dosed with deadly amounts of ionising radiation from the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we feel the Earth's rotation?

options.label: A
options.text: The change in velocity is just too gradual.

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's rotation is too slow.

multiple-choice.question: What is the definition of a second?

options.label: B
options.text: The time it takes for the Earth to rotate once on its axis.

options.label: C
options.text: The time it takes for the Earth to orbit the Sun once.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of oscillations between two levels of an atom of cesium 133.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the irregularity in the Earth's rotation speed?

options.label: A
options.text: The uneven distribution of mass on the Earth's surface.

options.label: B
options.text: The gravitational pull of the Moon.

options.label: C
options.text: The movement of the Earth's axis.

options.label: D
options.text: The change in the Earth's radius.

options.label: C

title: Feedback loops: How nature gets its rhythms - Anje-Margriet Neutel

multiple-choice.question: What is the key element that makes everything work in the grand orchestra of nature?
What is an example of positive feedback in the natural world?

options.label: A
options.text: When plants die, the dead material enriches the soil with humus.

options.label: B
options.text: When plants grow, the more humus is produced, allowing even more plants to grow.

options.label: C
options.text: When removing a forest makes it vulnerable to erosion.

options.label: D
options.text: When predators and their prey populations decrease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the ongoing process of mutual causal interaction?

options.label: A
options.text: When lynx eat snowshoe hares, their population increases.

options.label: B
options.text: When lynx eat snowshoe hares, their population decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: When removing a forest makes it vulnerable to erosion.

options.label: D
options.text: When predators and their prey populations increase.

title: What can Schrödinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between the physics of everyday phenomena and the physics of atoms?

options.label: A
options.text: The physics of atoms is much slower than the physics of everyday phenomena.

options.label: B
options.text: The physics of atoms is much faster than the physics of everyday phenomena.

options.label: C
options.text: The physics of atoms behaves according to the laws of classical mechanics, while the physics of everyday phenomena behaves according to the laws of quantum mechanics.

options.label: D
options.text: The physics of atoms is only applicable to very large objects, while the physics of everyday phenomena is only applicable to very small objects.

multiple-choice.question: What is a superposition state?

options.label: A
options.text: A state where a physical system is in one definite state.

options.label: B
options.text: A state where a physical system is in a mixture of multiple states.

options.label: C
options.text: A state where a physical system is not affected by external forces.

options.label: D
options.text: A state where a physical system is at absolute zero temperature.

multiple-choice.question: What is entanglement in quantum mechanics?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where two physical systems are connected by a physical link.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where two physical systems are in a superposition state.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where the state of one physical system is dependent on the state of another physical system, even when they are separated by large distances.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon where a physical system is in a definite state.

multiple-choice.question: What is the core of quantum information science?

options.label: C
options.text: The study of how to use the laws of the strange quantum world in our macroscopic world.

options.label: D
options.text: The study of the behavior of subatomic particles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of quantum cryptography?

options.label: A
options.text: To send insecure messages to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: To send secure messages to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the behavior of subatomic particles.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand the laws of quantum mechanics.

multiple-choice.question: What is quantum computing?

options.label: A
options.text: A method of solving complex mathematical problems using classical computers.

options.label: B
options.text: A method of solving complex mathematical problems using quantum computers.

options.label: C
options.text: A method of encrypting messages using classical computers.

options.label: D
options.text: A method of decrypting messages using quantum computers.

multiple-choice.question: What is quantum phenomenon is at the core of quantum information science?
What is the purpose of quantum teleportation?

options.label: A
options.text: To send secure messages to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: To send insecure messages to each other.

options.label: C
options.text: To transport information from one location to another without physical transport of the information.

options.label: D
options.text: To study the behavior of subatomic particles.

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where a cat is always alive.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where a cat is always dead.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where a cat is in a superposition state, both alive and dead at the same time.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that cats are always dead.

options.label: C
options.text: It illustrates the strange and beautiful phenomenon of quantum superposition.

options.label: D

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What was the devastating epidemic known as that destroyed as much as 1/5 of the world's population in the 14th century?
What was the main difference between the medieval Black Death and modern instances of plague?

options.label: A
options.text: The Black Death was spread by rodent fleas, while modern instances were spread directly from person to person.

options.label: B
options.text: The Black Death was spread directly from person to person, while modern instances were spread by rodent fleas.

options.label: C
options.text: The Black Death was caused by a different bacterium than modern instances of plague.

options.label: D
options.text: The Black Death was not caused by a bacterium at all.

multiple-choice.question: What was the likely cause of the high mortality rate of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: The bacterium that caused the disease was highly virulent.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The disease was spread by a highly efficient vector.

options.label: D
options.text: The population was not prepared to deal with the outbreak.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to a significant increase in social mobility and political reforms.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to a significant decrease in living standards and an increase in poverty.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: It had no significant impact on the gene pool of the population.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It may lead to a decrease in the mortality rate of the plague.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a threat only in certain countries.

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to a better understanding of how our world has been shaped by the past.

options.label: B
options.text: It may lead to the development of new treatments for the plague.

options.label: C
options.text: It may lead to a decrease in the mortality rate of the plague.

options.label: D
options.text: It may lead to a significant increase in the gene pool of the population.

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a significant increase in the gene pool of the population.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to a significant decrease in the gene pool of the population.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no significant impact on the gene pool of the population.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a significant increase in the mutation rate of the population.

options.label: A
options.text: It may lead to a better understanding of the causes and effects of the plague.

options.label: B

title: How optical illusions trick your brain - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is an optical illusion?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: An image that is exactly what it seems.

options.label: C
options.text: An image that is a copy of a real object.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of visual processing that ignores contrast between light and dark areas.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of visual processing that increases contrast between objects.

options.label: A
options.text: To create a 2D representation of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a 3D representation of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: A region of the brain that processes auditory information.

options.label: D
options.text: A region of the brain that processes tactile information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the brain's visual system?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a 2D representation of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a 3D representation of the world.

options.label: A
options.text: To create a 2D representation of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a 3D representation of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To process visual information from objects.

options.label: C
options.text: To process visual information from faces.

options.text: To create a 2D representation of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a 2D representation of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a 3D representation of the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the concept of optical illusions?

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the fish species shown in the video at two months old?

options.label: A
options.text: They lay eggs on the reef.

options.label: B
options.text: They release sperm and eggs into the water column.

options.label: C
options.text: They give birth to live young.

options.label: D
options.text: They undergo a process called parthenogenesis.

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique characteristic of many coral reef fish larvae?

options.label: A
options.text: They are weak swimmers and unable to move vertically in the water column.

options.label: B
options.text: They are strong swimmers and can move vertically in the water column to place themselves in different water masses.

options.label: C
options.text: They have gills from birth and are able to breathe easily.

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to photosynthesize and obtain energy from sunlight.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that coral reef fish larvae navigate to their adult habitats?

options.label: A
options.text: They use a complex suite of sensory systems, detecting both sound and smell.

options.label: B
options.text: They use a magnetic compass to navigate.

options.label: C
options.text: They follow the currents and drift with the water.

options.label: D
options.text: They are guided by the light of the sun.

options.label: B

options.label: D
